column4: I am trying to get inetd running..however when I try to apt-get install inetd it tells me it is already installed?
it better be! comes with ubuntu
Ok..so why isn't there an /etc/inetd.conf file for starters..and is it supposed to run from a new install?
what do you need to do what the file?
jump in #windows and I'll help you
The reason I asked here is I want to use Ubuntu to do this ;-)
oh I see, apt-get install nmap
then.. assuming the ips start with 192.168.0.*
this assumes windows is not blocking ping requests
if it is, you would need to connect to your router
Kewl that was what I was looking for..your assumption is correct and I can connect to the router...

Worked like a charm! However attempts to scan like nmap -sS 192.168.1.* results in a message that it can't do it...I assumed root privileges was regarding Ubuntu and not the computer I am trying to scan?
